Posts.Content: Apr 19, 2011 12:29PM lwd wrote: Hi Lynn, I read somewhere that SE's can include weight gain OR loss.  But, more seemed to gain weight than lose.  I've been fighting a little weight gain which seemed to start after the first year on Femara.  I'm not sure whether it might be partially the ageing process, and loss of estrogen.  Plus, I think my appetite has increased.  The weight is going around my middle, where it tends to go after menopause.  This never happened in my 50's, but now!! I seem to be able to lose 3-4 pounds if I really work at it.  I do wonder, though, if some of it is water weight.  A week ago I was so bloated and was up 3 pounds at the dr.  Then 2 days ago I was in the bathroom every half hour, and now I feel great.  So, that 3 pounds must have been fluids.  I seem to need to watch more closely what I eat and make sure I drink lots of water, or my weight fluctuates, regardless of the calorie intake.  Who knows?  But, I do hate that everything is shifting towards the center! I think there's only so much we can do, and I HATE THAT!  Just one more way to feel loss of control.  Let me know if you find the answer!  And, hope you have a wonderful trip. Lane

Posts.Content: May 12, 2010 01:02PM lwd wrote: It's so important that we know what's going on.  It gives us somewhat of a feeling of control.  A pleural effusion was the first sign of my BC metastasis, along with a lump on my sternum.  I felt very full and had difficulty taking a deep breath.  It showed on a CT scan.  I had 3 thoracenteses within a 6-week period to drain the fluid.  Cancer cells were present when the fluid was tested the first time.  Since mine is ER/PR+ I was treated with Femara.  After 6 months the fluid had disappeared from the PET scan.  I've had no more effusion for almost a year.  My onc said that when the time comes that the Femara stops working pleural effusion may likely occur again. Since I'm on my first round of meds for metastasis, can anyone tell me whether, when their particular meds stopped working, the cancer returned in the same spots?

Posts.Content: Oct 10, 2010 08:49AM lwd wrote: Hello, Dola, Perhaps your friend had breast cancer previously.  In my case, I had a very small lump in the breast 13 years ago and was treated with lumpectomy and radiation.  Then, about 2 years ago, I found out I am Stage IV, with no detectable cancer in the breast, but cancer in the sternum and lung pleura.  My onc thinks 13 years ago cells escaped through the blood stream or lympthatic system at the time of, or before or after my treatment and are now detectable in other areas.  Tests on these more recent tumors show similarity to the original BC cells.  So, at some point the conditions were right for the cells to start multiplying again.  It is still considered BC because the cells are BC cells, even though this time they didn't show up in the breast.  I wish my best for your friend, Lane

My kids are in their early 30's, so I know it would be much more difficult if they were much younger.  I keep them filled in on my scans, treatment, etc.  And, from the beginning we told them what the onc told us - probably 5 years, and a possibility of much longer, but it could be sooner.  I'm glad it's out in the open, knowing how quickly things can change.  I wouldn't want them to think that they would have done anything differently, if only they had known.  And, my daughter had her first mammogram, which was fine and gave us all peace of mind. Posts.Content: Oct 16, 2010 11:04PM lwd wrote: Linnette, I've been on Femara for 20 months.  After 8 months the SE's began - muscle, joint, bone aches and pains, wrists hurt, sometimes feet, stiffness and pain when I first stand up.  Sound familiar?  My SE's are manageable with ibuprofen.  I have found that exercise helps.  Although I also have fatigue, just being up and around does make my muscles feel better.  First thing in the morning it's so hard getting out of bed.  I truly think exercise helps.  It sounds like you have more pain than I have.  I'd talk to your onc about maybe trying a different AI and getting help with the pain. Femara has kept me NED for 18 months and began working almost immediately.  It did its job for me.  I would consider help with the SE's first, rather than stopping the Femara; but, you know best what you can tolerate.  The SE's are worse for some, I know.  I hope you can get this worked out; I've heard that the SE's might diminish with time, too.  I hear you, though, girl! Posts.Content: Dec 3, 2010 11:50AM lwd wrote: You've all given me a good laugh this morning!  What we go through! I can't think of anything too humilating recently, although the sweaty armpit thing is something I endure often.  At least the doc can remove his gloves and toss them out afterward! But, remembering back 14 years to my first rad treatment after lumpectomy.  Don't know if they photographed any of you.  Maybe by now they are a little more sensitive.  But I had to sit in a chair and have my boobs photographed (one with an unsightly scar).  They put the photo on my chart.  So they could identify me by boob?  in case they got the wrong patient in there?  Or for legal purposes in case the damage from the rads was excessive?  WHO KNOWS??  I didn't ask.  But, right when they were ready to take the photo, a gorgeous young male tech came in.  These days it wouldn't bother me as much.  But, I was much younger then, and my pride took a serious hit.  Plus, I was so depressed and still in denial at the time.  Guess I'll never forget it.  It's something I can only this many years later laugh about (a little). It still brings back horrid memories and feelings. Sorry, guess I got off track.  Best to talk about things that make me laugh! Love you all.  Nice that we still can keep a sense of humor, isn't it?  Amazing, really! Lane

Posts.Content: Aug 7, 2010 02:12PM lwd wrote: In my last post I forgot to mention that I believe that low Vit D levels may also cause foot pain.  About 2 years before I was diagnosed with metastasis I had problems with my feet.  At work, after sitting for a while (same as it is today), I'd get up and could hardly walk.  The bottoms of my feet felt like pins and needles for only a minute, then I was fine.  Shortly after, although I didn't make any connection at the time, I was diagnosed with extremely low Vit D and was put on 50,000 iu's/day for a couple of months, to get it back to normal.  Now I take 2,000/day maintenance and have it checked once a year.  Last year I read that there seems to be a connection with low D and breast cancer, and my onc also mentioned that.  Could it be my cancer was returning way back then and I had no clue, until other symptoms appeared? We can drive ourselves crazy thinking about it all, and searching for new lumps, huh?  Now that I'm 18 months out and still on my first treatment, Femara and Zometa, I'm really starting to worry that soon the Femara might stop working, and what's next?  Have to keep telling myself that this is the way life is now, and I'd better get used to it!  It helps to share with you all. Lane   Lane

Posts.Content: Sep 16, 2010 10:20AM lwd wrote: Welcome.  You'll have much support and love here!  I'm also ER+ and have had good results with Femara and Zometa.  I have mets to bone (sternum) and left lung pleura.  The Zometa has been shown to build bone as well as stop progression in the bones, and it has worked for me.  We are each different.  I know the stats are frightening.  I was shocked when I did the research.  Now I try to avoid categorizing myself.  There are lots who are long-term survivors.  I wish you the best and know how difficult this is.  Keep in touch with us.  It's wonderful to be able to discuss and sometimes let loose and rant with others who are in the same position.  I also have a daughter (30 yrs).  She worries about me, and I worry about her.  So many changes in our lives.  Things we prayed that would never happen, and so hard to believe and understand.  Try to keep courage.  Not so easy, I know.   Hugs, Lane

Posts.Content: Oct 14, 2010 11:20AM lwd wrote: Sarika, I haven't had chemo, so can only imagine what is going through your mom's mind.  I know when the time comes that I'm told chemo is my only option it will be a huge decision for me to make.  I'm 60, had my first bout with BC almost 14 years ago, so I did have lots of great years  between diagnoses.  I am so grateful for that time.  My onc thinks I might have a few more years on anti-hormonals since I have responded so well for the past 20 months.  The cancer has been in my lung pleura and my bones.  Right now I'm of the mind that I probably will not do chemo.  I'm sure that's easier to say now when not faced with an immediate decision.  I think if I were younger, and maybe with children still at home, I might not think twice about choosing chemo.  But at this point in my life, QOL is major for me.  I've had a wonderful life and don't want my children or husband or myself to have to deal with potential side effects of chemo only to add maybe a few months to my life.  I also have Alzheimer's on both sides of my family and watched the suffering of my mom for 10 years.  Perhaps I won't get Alzheimers, but I truly think I'd rather die an earlier death from BC than put my family through what we dealt with with my Mom.  I've joked with my 2 sisters that if they notice signs of Alzheimer's, to be sure and tell me, and I'll stop taking my Femara.  I've never been one to think that living to a ripe old age is always a good thing, when I think of what most go through at the end.  I think living longer, as we tend to do these days, is not always better.  I do not want to end up in a nursing home for years.  If I knew there was a cure for me, though, I might feel differently.  So, for now I'll try to live it up, enjoy my time while I'm feeling pretty good, and hope for the best.  It's a personal decision each of us has to make, and each situation is different.  However difficult it is, I know how much you love your mom, and hope that you'll be able to work through this and reach a decision which will give you both comfort and peace.  For now, provide her all the love and support you can.  I'm fortunate that my family is doing that for me. Hugs to you and your mom, Lane

Posts.Content: Aug 5, 2010 06:18PM lwd wrote: I'm on Femara and Zometa and have been for 18 months.  My first Zometa treatment left me with flu symptoms for a day, then no problems until last month the same thing happened.  I DO have SE's from Femara, which are muscle and joint pain and pain in the feet (can hardly walk first thing in the morning).  Do you happen to be on an AI?  The lack of estrogen can cause these symptoms.   Make sure you are well hydrated before and after your Zometa treatment.  This might help.  Also, if they draw out the infusion for 30 min. rather than 15 it might help, also.  You might not have any further problems with this.  Sometimes it's only the first treatment which will bother you.  I attribute my last SE's to not staying hydrated after my treatment.  I should have known better, but have this problem with not getting thirsty.  Hope this helps! Lane

Posts.Content: Jan 20, 2013 08:11PM lwd wrote: Okay, I'm ready.  It appears we've recently had some "WESTERN GIRLS", including Stormynite and Kay (also from CO), Spamgirl (aha, THAT'S where the Spam came from), and Chrissy, WAY, WAY west! 1)  Ah, how do I get that relaxed feeling?  I wish I could say, Yoga, or relaxation exercises.  But, sadly, no.  My first thought is a long, hot bath with dimmed lights, candles, and a large glass of red wine by my side, or maybe a stiff Marguerita on the rocks - not the limeade version. Also, the absence of Lovenox injections, Thoracentesis needles, and, really, just the absence of a hospital environment does tend to aid relaxation. A great book in my comfortable chair with my sweet golden Retriever's head on my lap. 2)  Where do I live?  Monument, CO, almost equadistant from Denver and Colorado Springs.  We love the mountains and the climate.  Much milder than you'd expect being just east of the mountains, as I think one of the other CO girls mentioned.  Weekend trips to mountain towns, parks and resorts, wildlife, cities just far enough away that we still feel we live in the country yet have access to city life.  We also love trips to New Mexico, which is only a hop, skip and jump away, and which explains my love of Margueritas, the non-limeade kind. My husband and I grew up in the west and have lived in Utah, Alaska and CO.  We landed here almost 30 years ago and don't intend to leave. 3) What do or did I do for work?  I've always loved to travel, but as so often happens, ended up on a different path.  I have a degree in business and spent a good portion of my adult life in the insurance industry, of all things.  But, I always kept the dream of traveling in the back of my mind. In the end, I got it, if only for 3 years.  The year I retired I enrolled within 2 months in a travel school and became a tour manager.  I led 7 small-group tours to Italy and loved every minute.  They PAY you for this!  Not much, but hey!   During this time I was diagnosed with a recurrence after 12 years.  I was determined and able to keep working during that time, and made it happen.  I still can't believe my good fortune at being able to make that dream come true. 4)  Do I enjoy craft work?  I was more involved in crafts years ago, although I still enjoy knitting.  I used to knit sweaters and afghans, now I'm happy with smaller projets, such as hats and scarves. Years ago I did cross stitch, latchhook rugs (do they still do those?), needlepoint, crochet, embroidery, sewing, and knitting.  I never did macrame for some reason, although I was a 70's child of the universe.  I do remember knitting socks for a boyfriend and even red, white and blue boxer shorts!  Can you imagine?  Itchy!  I remember him saying his mom was shocked when they showed up in the laundry.  I was shocked that he actually wore them! 5)  Am I happy with my life choices?  YES!  Over all I've been very fortunate and have few regrets.  No one has a perfect life.  Don't the good parts stand out as excellent after we've experienced the not-so-good?  And, now facing a shorter life span than I'd expected, I try to keep the "no regrets" attitude as I move forward, day by day.  I am planning a trip to Italy in April, keeping in mind that it might not happen, but if it does, it will be great.   If it doesn't, what fun I've had planning it.  The bonus question:  My favorite time of the day has recently become early morning, as the sun rises through the pine trees in my back yard.  Sometimes I'm awake at 4 a.m.  Well, when you go to bed at 8!! I love to have coffee and read in my favorite chair while keeping an eye on birds and squirrels as the sun comes up.  This morning 4 deer wandered through.  I love it even when the sun reaches the angle which showcases my dirty windows.  Maybe tomorrow I should get out the ladder.....or not. Now I'll be thinking about the next 5 Questions, and who will have some interesting answers.  Have a nice weekend!

Posts.Content: Nov 12, 2010 05:05PM lwd wrote: Suebus, I tend to agree with those who say, "everything in moderation."  I kind of went nuts with the healthy living stuff after my first diagnosis 13 years ago, although I've always been active and have been a healthy eater.  When it came back as mets I thought about going totally organic, etc.  But have reached the conclusion that, for me, I will not make drastic diet changes, but will reduce intake of red meats and fats, drink organic milk, eat lots of fresh fruits and veggies, and continue to exercise.  I honestly don't think my diet contributed to my recurrence.  But, I do feel better on a healthier diet.  We're all different.  I would say, don't go hog-wild thinking you'll make major changes.  Sometimes it just doesn't work, and you might be setting yourself up for disappointment. The way I look at it, especially now, is, I'm going to have a dessert once in a while, if I crave it, and I'll continue to have a glass of wine occasionally.  I'm going to enjoy this life while I have it and not deprive myself nor let myself feel guilty.  QOL is too important to me.  I would say do what you feel is best, what you can incorporate into your lifestyle easily and with undue stress.  But don't beat yourself up over it.  I do understand what you are going through. Hugs, Lane

Posts.Content: Aug 9, 2010 12:52PM lwd wrote: Hi, I'm ER+ also.  First diagnosed 13 years ago.  Recurrence with metastasis 18 months ago, to lung pleura, sternum and lymph node.  Femara and Zometa from the get-go.  They started to work very quickly, and within a year there was NED!  So, I'm at 18 months now, on the same drugs.  Hoping they'll continue to work a long time, which I know they do for some.  My onc said there are many other AI's he can try when the Femara stops working, before he would try chemo.  I feel pretty good over all, and am adjusting to the SE's.  One of the most difficult things for me has been trying to adjust to the "not being able to plan."  I've always been a planner, like others have mentioned here.  And the feeling of loss of control is overwhelming at times.  I'm trying to live in the present, as we all should do whether faced with a terminal illness or not.  Trying to plan things I need or want to do not more than 2 months out, to lessen the feelings of disappointment if things change.  It's not easy to do, but helps me keep things manageable.  Also, I make lists, and try to accomplish little tasks and do things that make me feel better, just a few at a time, daily.  This helps me feel more in control, and satisfied that I've done something worthwhile.  IT AIN'T EASY!  And, it's a different kind of life, for sure. At times I still can't believe it is happening.  Take time to pamper yourself.  You're definitely worth it.  Living for today sounded easy before this happened.  I have to keep telling myself that being miserable is ruining the time I have.  I do have a choice whether to be happy or sad.  It works most of the time.  Try not to be hard on yourself when you get down.  It happens to all of us.  You have lots of support out here! Lane

Posts.Content: Aug 10, 2010 01:04PM lwd wrote: Terri, Let's keep in touch.  Also all you others out there who are ER+ and just starting on AI's.  I know some have been on Femara for several years with NED.  Hard to say what is average, but guess it depends on how aggressive the cancer is.  I started 12 years ago, then it came back.  Onc thinks it must have spread from the teensy tumor before my treatment (lumpectomy + rads), then remained dormant all those years, settling in the bones and lung pleura.  He did say "long time growing usually means longer time to get under control."  But, in my case the Femara and Zometa started working within a few weeks.  Seems the Femara starved the tumors of estrogen.  The lung took a little longer.  I had to have 3 thoracenteses (draining of the lung pleura).   My onc also said (when I asked), that I'll probably have the same symptoms when the drug stops working, i.e., lung problems and tumor on my sternum will return.  It usually returns to the same areas, but sometimes new places as well.   Good luck, and keep in touch! Lane
